isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 570 / HT 570 Diesel Engine Diagnostic Manual - 2004 Emissions with EGR - Engine Symptoms Diagnostics - Problems and Conditions

svcsubsecinfo.para: Diagnostic test procedures help technicians systematically find problems quickly to avoid unnecessary repairs. In this section, diagnostic and test procedures help identify causes for known problems and conditions.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the foreword of this manual. Follow all warnings, cautions, and notes.

svcproc.title: Combustion Leaks to Coolant
svcproc.para: Combustion leaks can be identified by coolant overflowing from deaeration tank or air bubbles in the coolant.

item.para: Failed injector sleeve
Failed air compressor
Failed head gasket
Failed EGR cooler
Porous or cracked cylinder sleeve

svcproc.para: The likely cause of combustion gas leakage to the cooling system is past the injector sleeve in the cylinder head. A failed cylinder head gasket or porous / cracked cylinder sleeve is possible. However, this should not be considered unless there is evidence of engine overheating or high engine mileage without proper coolant conditioning.

item.para: Radiator pressure testing kit
Plastic surge tank cap adapter
Cylinder head test plate
Water supply housing pressure adapter
Thermostat opening pressure adapter (cylinder head)
Hose pinch-off pliers (2)

step1.para: Is the engine equipped with an air compressor?

item.para: If yes, do step 2.
If no, do step 3.

step1.para: Close off both coolant hoses for the air compressor with hose pinch-off pliers. Test the system again.

item.para: If coolant continues overflowing from the deaeration tank, do step 3.
If coolant stops overflowing from deaeration tank, repair or replace the air compressor.

step1.para: Remove injectors following the procedure in the Engine Service Manual.

figure.caption: Cylinder head cut-away with injector sleeve

step1.para: Install radiator pressure tester with the appropriate adapter.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death and damage to the engine:

item.para: Always allow the engine to cool for 15 minutes.
Wrap a thick cloth around the cap.
Loosen cap slowly a quarter to half turn.
Pause for a moment to avoid water or steam scalding.
Continue to turn the cap and remove.
Never add cold coolant to a hot engine. This can result in a cracked cylinder head or crankcase.
Never use water as a coolant substitute.

step1.para: Pressurize cooling system to 96 kPa (14 psi).
Look for coolant leaking around the injector sleeve and into the cylinder bore.

item.para: If a leak is noticed, replace the leaking injector sleeve and test again.
If no leak is noticed, replace all six injector sleeves and test again.
If coolant continues to flow into cylinders after all injector sleeves were replaced, do step 7.

step1.para: Remove cylinder head from engine, perform all inspections, and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Follow the procedure in the Engine Service Manual.

item.para: Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks.
Verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.
Check cylinder liner protrusion.

step1.para: Test the cylinder head with pressure test plate to validate the repair.
